text:
DISEASES 

Any disturbance in the body of a living organism which interferes with the normal functioning of one part or more of its parts. In this section we will be discussing diseases that UNN normally ask questions on.

Fleas are vectors for viral, bacterial and rickettsia diseases of humans and other animals, as well as of protozoan and helminth parasites. Bacterial diseases carried by fleas include murine or endemic typhus and bubonic plague.

Loa loa microfilaria found in blood film. Loa loa is the filarial nematode (roundworm) species that causes Loa loa filariasis. Loa loa actually means "worm worm", but is commonly known as the "eye worm", as it localizes to the conjunctiva of the eye. Loa loa is commonly found in Africa.

The adult Filarial worms only live in the human lymph system. The lymph system maintains the body's fluid balance and fights infections. In the lymphactic duct they clug up with blood vessels and cause body parts enlargement. 

Pinworm infections are caused by worm-like parasites (Enterobius vermicularis) that infect humans' intestines and rectal/anal areas.

Dracunculiasis, also known as Guinea worm disease (GWD), is an infection caused by the parasite Dracunculus medinensis. A parasite is an organism that feeds off of another to survive. GWD is spread by drinking water containing Guinea worm larvae.

Ancylostoma duodenale is a species of the roundworm genus Ancylostoma. It is a parasitic nematode worm and commonly known as the Old-World hookworm. It lives in the small intestine of hosts such as humans, cats and dogs, where it can mate and mature.

Taenia solium, the pork tapeworm of man, as adult lives in the intestine of man leading an endoparasitic life. Its life history is completed in two hosts, i.e., digenetic; man being the primary host and pig as secondary host.

The life cycle of tapeworms is indirect. It passes through pigs, as intermediate hosts, into humans, as definitive hosts. From humans, the eggs are released in the environment where they await ingestion by another host. Humans as the definitive hosts are directly infected from contaminated meat.

The main vector of malaria parasite is the infected female anopheles mosquito which transmit the parasite (Plasmodium). 

Lymphatic filariasis is caused by the worms Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori. These worms occupy the lymphatic system, including the lymph nodes; in chronic cases, these worms lead to the syndrome of elephantiasis.

The spleen is an organ found in virtually all vertebrates. Similar in structure to a large lymph node, it acts primarily as a blood filter. The spleen plays important roles in regard to red blood cells (erythrocytes) and the immune system.

Haemophilia is a mostly inherited genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to make blood clots, a process needed to stop bleeding. It is treated by replacing the missing blood clotting factors

Scurvy is a condition caused by a severe lack of vitamin C in the diet. People who don't include enough fruits and vegetables in their diet are at risk.

Reiter’s Syndrome (now known as Reactive Arthritis) develops in response to an infection and characterized by a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and nonspecific urethritis. It is considered an autoimmune disease marked by inflammatory synovitis and erosion at the insertion sites of ligaments and tendons.

Cretinism refers to severe hypothyroidism in an infant or child. This is classically the result of maternal iodine deficiency, and thankfully is increasingly rare.

The pathogen causing Guinea Worm disease is the nematode Dracunculiasis Medinensis, and the vector is the Cyclops or water flea.

Dracunculiasis is a parasitic infection acquired by drinking water from ponds contaminated by cyclopoid copepods infected with third stage larvae of the parasite Dracunculus medinensis.

In Igboland, Guinea worm is a common health problem in many water bodies in Ebonyi state and in Igwenu river basin area of Imo state. 

Leishmaniasis is a vector borne disease that is transmitted by sand flies and caused by obligate intracellular protozoa of the genus. It is a human blood parasite responsible for visceral leishmaniasis or kala-azar, the most severe form of leishmaniasis.

When your body is dehydrated (low water), your mind and body cannot function at their best. Your body will show symptoms when it is dehydrated – such as darker urine, and lack of sweat when exercising.

Pneumonia: Pneumonia is a lung disease. Excessive cold may cause disease. Excessive cold after.

Cause

Pneumonia is caused by pneumococcus bacteria.

Symptoms

- Deposition of mucus like liquid substances which produce cough.

- Coughing and breathing distress.

- High fever and chest pain.

- Severe respiratory distress, at the last stage whizzing sound in the chest.

 

Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is well known air borne infectious disease. Tuberculosis occurs at any organ of the body. Such as- intestine, bone, lung etc. When the germs destroy white blood corpuscles, body become weak then the symptoms are exposed.

Cause

The disease is caused by tubercle basillus, a type of bacterium. This germ spreads in un healthy environment easily.

Symptoms and signs

 - weight loss, general weakness.

- Usually cough and cold continues more than three weeks.

- Coughing, sometimes cough up blood. Evening sweat and rise of low fever.

- Chest pain, indigestion, abdominal diseases.

 

Kidney stone: Small stone-like substances produced by kidney is known as kidney stone. Anyone can be attacked by these diseases. But it has been noticed that the male has the higher possibility of stone formation than the female. Excessive body weight/obesity, infection in kidney, drinking insufficient water, in taking of excessive protein e.g. meat and eggs are the causes of kidney stones.

 

UNN PUTME Examples

1. The habitat of the cysticercus of Taenia solium is____

A. alimentary canal of cattle B. muscle of pig C. alimentary canal of pig D. muscle of cattle

(B. Habit and Habitat of Taenia Solium: Taenia solium, the pork tapeworm of man, as adult lives in the intestine of man leading an endoparasitic life. Its life history is completed in two hosts, i.e., digenetic; man being the primary host and pig as secondary host, 2015/2016, no 13)

 

2. The main vector of malaria parasite is

A. culex mosquito B. chrysops C. anopheles mosquito D. aedes mosquito

(C. The main vector of malaria parasite is the infected female anopheles mosquito which transmit the parasite (Plasmodium), 2005/2006, no 13)

 

3. In which region of the human body does the adult filarial worm reside? 

A. Muscle B. Nervous system C. Blood D. Lymph 

(D. The adult Filarial worms only live in the human lymph system. The lymph system maintains the body's fluid balance and fights infections. In the lymphactic duct they clug up with blood vessels and cause body parts enlargement, 2018/2019, no 2)

 

4. A severe deficiency thyroxin results in _____

A. diabetes Mellitus B. sexual underdevelopment C. cretinism D. gigantism

(C. Cretinism refers to severe hypothyroidism in an infant or child. This is classically the result of maternal iodine deficiency, and thankfully is increasingly rare, 2015/2016 II, no 14)

 

5. The eye worm is known as

A. Wuchereiria bancrofti B. Brugia malayi C. Loa loa D. Dracunenlus rnedinensis

(C. Loa loa microfilaria found in blood film. Loa loa is the filarial nematode (roundworm) species that causes Loa loa filariasis. Loa loa actually means "worm worm", but is commonly known as the "eye worm", as it localizes to the conjunctiva of the eye. Loa loa is commonly found in Africa, 2008/2009, no 8)

 

6. A sex-linked defect that allows small cuts to bleed severely is known as

A. anaemia B. anorexia C. haemophilia D. haemolysis 

(C. Haemophilia is a mostly inherited genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to make blood clots, a process needed to stop bleeding. It is treated by replacing the missing blood clotting factors, 2009/2010, no 10)

 

7. If a person lives exclusively on a diet of milk, egg and bread, he is likely to suffer from

A. Scurvy B. Rickets C. Beri-beri D. Night blindness

(A. Scurvy is a condition caused by a severe lack of vitamin C in the diet, 2010/2011, no 15)

 

8. Leishmania donovani causes

A. Kala-azar B. Elephantiasis C. Sleeping sickness D. Malaria

(A. Leishmaniasis is a vector borne disease that is transmitted by sand flies and caused by obligate intracellular protozoa of the genus. It is a human blood parasite responsible for visceral leishmaniasis or kala-azar, the most severe form of leishmaniasis, 2011/2012, no 9)

 

9. In which region of the human body does the adult filarial worm reside?

A. Muscle B. Nervous system C. Blood D. Lymph

(D. The adult Filarial worms only live in the human lymph system. The lymph system maintains the body's fluid balance and fights infections, 2011/2012, no 10)

 

10. Washing cuts and wounds with salt solution can

A. make them salty B. prevent them from being infected C. damage them even more D. be dangerous for the person

(B. Saltwater can help heal wounds faster by preventing it from being infected, 2012/2013, no 4)

 

11. The vector for Guinea worm is

A. Female Anopheles mosquito B. Culex mosquito C. Cyclops D. Aedes mosquito

(C. The pathogen causing Guinea Worm disease is the nematode Dracunculiasis Medinensis, and the vector is the Cyclops or water flea, 2012/2013, no 5)

 

12. Which one of the following pairs is correctly matched?

A. Enterobius vermicular - guinea worm B. Loa loa - eye worm C. Dracunculus medinensis - pin worm

D. Ancylostoma duodenale - filarial worm

(B. Loa loa is the filarial nematode species that causes Loa loa filariasis. Loa loa actually means "worm worm", but is commonly known as the "eye worm", as it localizes to the conjunctiva of the eye. Loa loa is commonly found in Africa, 2012/2013, no 15)

 

13. Which of the following is never a secondary host of tapeworm?

A. man B. fish C. pig D. dog 

(A. The life cycle of tapeworms (Taenia solium) is indirect. It passes through pigs, as intermediate hosts, into humans, as definitive hosts. From humans, the eggs are released in the environment where they await ingestion by another host. Humans as the definitive hosts are directly infected from contaminated meat, 2017/2018 II, no 5)

 

14. An old man is likely to be long-sighted because age affects the 

A. optic nerves B. retina C. ciliary muscles D. cornea

(C. Presbyopia is an age-related long-sightedness is called presbyopia. It is a gradual thickening and loss of elasticity of the natural lens inside the eye and ciliary muscle, making them ridged in relaxed state, and therefore making the eye unable to see near object, 2019/2020, no 8)

 

15. Reiter's syndrome is the name given to a form of

A. body odour B. stomach disorder C. infectious arthritis D. gout

(C. Reiter’s Syndrome (now known as Reactive Arthritis) develops in response to an infection and characterized by a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and nonspecific urethritis, 2012/2013, no 12)

 

JAMB Examples

1. Exo-erythrocytic phase of the life cycle of malaria parasite occurs in the

A. liver of humans B. reticuloendothelial cells of humans C. Malpighian tubules of mosquito D. brain of humans

(A. liver of humans)

 

2. Dracunculiasis can be contracted through

A. eating contaminated food B. drinking contaminated water C. bathing in contaminated water D. bites of blackfly

(B. drinking contaminated water)

 

3. The diseases caused by water-borne pathogens include

A. gonorrhoea and poliomyelitis B. typhoid and syphilis C. tuberculosis and cholera D. typhoid and cholera

(D. typhoid and cholera)

 

4. An example of a parasitic protozoan is

A. Paramecium B. Plasmodium C. Euglena D. Chlamydomonas

(B. Plasmodium)

 

5. The organelle responsible for osmoregulation in Paramecium is 

A. flame cell B. nephridia C. contractile vacuole D. Malpighian tubule

(C. contractile vacuole)

 

6. Which of the following is caused by Treponema palladium?

A. Gonorrhoea B. Leprosy C. Tuberculosis D. Syphilis

(D. Syphilis)

 

7. The eye defect cause by the development of cloudy areas in the lenses is

A. presbyopia B. glaucoma C. cataract D. astigmatism

(C. Cataract)

 

8. The eye defect that rises because the cornea is not curved smoothly is 

A. astigmatism B. short-sightedness C. long-sightedness D. presbyopia

(A. astigmatism)

 

9. The causative organism of cholera is 

A. Clostridium sp B. shigella sp C. vibrio sp D. salmonella typhi

(C. vibrio sp)

 

10. The causative agent of Poliomyelitis is

A. Virus B. Fungus C. Protozoan D. Bacterium

(A. Virus)

 

11. Which of the following is true of small pox?

A. It is transmitted by bacteria B. It can effectively be controlled with antibiotics

C. It can effectively be controlled by vaccination D. It is a water-borne infection

(C. It can effectively be controlled by vaccination)

 

12. Severe diarrhea, dehydration and weakness are symptoms of 

A. cholera B. chickenpox C. malaria D. yellow fever

(D. yellow fever)

 

13. A boy who is fond of swimming in a pond finds himself passing urine with traces of blood. He is likely to have contracted 

A. schistosomiasis B. onchocerciasis C. poliomyelitis D. salmonellosis

(A. schistosomiasis)
